Dear Burrows, I enclose a copy of a letter I have received from Mr. Allcard, the Manager of Messrs Gray Mackenzie & Co., Limited in Bahrain, from which you will see that he wishes (a) to obtain a contract for landing cargo in Qatar; (b) to establish an office at Doha; (c) to obtain an exclusive concession to v act as steamer agents in Qatar, and (d) to act as purchasing agents for the Shaikh. 2. My comments are that while there is considerable criticism of Gray Mackenzie’s work, they, neverthless, are an important factor in our position in the Gulf because of their shipping associations. In 1944, the Bahrain Petroleum Company quarelled with them and only after great difficulty was the matter settled and Gray Mackenzie re-established in their position vis-a-vis Bahrein Petroleum Company. His Majesty’s Government’s attitude at that time was that they ’’attach great importance to doing all that is possible to assist Gray Mackenzie to maintain their position in Bahrain”. 3. As regards (a): I see no objection. Their establishment outside Petroleum Concessions work would increase the British position in Qatar, (b); and (c): no objection. As regards (d): I have no objection but suggest that (a), (b) and (c) be dealt with first. 4. As regards the Treaty position; Article 7 of the Treaty of 1916 is held in abeyance by Sir Percy Cox’s letter of the 3rd November, 1916, and before Gray Mackenzie may approach the Shaikh of Qatar it is necessary that the Political Agent should consult the Shaikh and obtain his agreement to allow British subjects into Qatar for purposes of trade in which, ofcourse, is included landing arrangements. I should be grateful for instructions that I may ask Pelly to ask the Shaikh to permit British subjects to enter Qatar for purposes Of trade. Gray Mackenzie would then be free to approach the Shaikh. Yours sincerely, Sd/- VM^HAY^ A C.&^UL-Cr^JA'i B.A.B. Burrows, Esq., Foreign Office, London. ? ' 1 -1EQE. copy(E 12948/327/91) FOREIGN OFFICE, S.W.l, 7th December, 1948 RESTRICTED, Dear Hay, . Please refer to Galloway’s letter No,(90/4/48) of 27th September about Gray Mackenzie’s application for a contract to land cargo in Qatar etc. We thought this provided as with a good opportunity to mention to Gray Mackenzies some of the criticisms about their work which have recently come to our notice, and to point out to them that while we were only too glad to do all in our power to promote the interests of British Companies in this area, there was none the less a strong obligation on them to ensure that the service they provided was at least as efficient, if not more efficient than anything else obtainable, and that they must do everything possible to reduce grounds of complaint to a minimum. Mr, Batley, the representative of the company who discussed the matter with us, agreed that this obligation did exist, and while remarking that many of the complaints, which had hitherto been-made against them had on investigation proved.to be ill-founded, assured us that his company were doing every thing in their power to improve their service in the Persian Gulf, and to eliminate any justifiable causes of complaint,. We accordingly agreed to authorise you to take such action as you consider necessary to further their application for a contract in Qatar. I should, therefore, be grateful if you would now ask Pelly to approach the Shaikh with a view to securing permission fornBritish subjects to enter Qatar for purposes of trade. Gray Mackenzie may there-after pursue the matter on their own behalf. I am sending a copy of this letter to Baghdad and Basra, as we took the opportunity to refer in conversation with Batley to reports (in Basra monthly summaries of earlier this year) about the labour conditions of the company’s employees at Basra. Tours ever, Sd. B.A. BURROWS. Sir Rupert Hay, KCIE., CSI., Bahrain. (TRUE COPY)RESTRICTED. Dear Wilton Allcard came to see me this morning about some instructions passed to Gray Mackenzie in Qatar by Shaikh Ali through the local Customs. They were to the effect that Gray Mackenzie should cease sending Bahrainis on ships to unload cargo in Qatar and employ local labour instead. 2, Gray Mackenzie maintain as a principle that these men are members of the ships’ crew and as such unloading is part of their work whatever port they may be in. physicalDescription.extent: The papers in the file are arranged chronologically. There are file notes at the end, on folios 36-38. The notes are arranged chronologically and refer to documents within the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 39; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. A previous foliation sequence, which is also circled, has been superseded and therefore crossed out.

mods.abstract: The file contains correspondence sent and received by the Political Agent at Bahrain concerning the operations of Gray Mackenzie & Co Ltd in Qatar, and the company's attempt to reach a lighterage agreement with the Ruler of Qatar.
